title: Electricity, Circuits, and Energy

vocab.definition: A form of energy that can power machines and lights
A complete path that electricity can follow
A material that electricity can flow through easily
A material that electricity cannot flow through easily
A common insulator used to cover wires for safety
A device that stores electrical energy
A device that opens or closes a circuit
The flow of electric charge through a circuit
A complete path so current can flow
A break in the path so current cannot flow
A circuit with one path where components are connected one after another
A circuit with more than one path for current to flow
A device in a circuit that uses electrical energy (like a bulb or motor)
A light in a circuit that glows when current flows
An accidental low-resistance path that can make too much current flow
The end point on a battery or device where wires connect
What provides energy for a circuit, like a battery
A clip used to connect wires to battery terminals
Things we use in a circuit or test, like wires, bulbs, or metals
A basic circuit with just a few parts like a battery, wires, and a bulb

teachingNotes: Use simple circuit kits to demonstrate how electricity flows. Test various materials to identify conductors and insulators. Discuss electrical safety and the importance of complete circuits.
